Title.evidence: Personalized Pain Education and Management in Orthopaedic Trauma: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Intervention.evidence: The intervention consisted of personalized pain education and management by coaches, while the control group received standard written discharge instructions.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of personalized pain education and management

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the mean pain score at 12 weeks, measured using the pain numeric rating scale.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Conducted between February 2021 and September 2022, 212 patients were randomised to either the intervention group (104 patients) or the control group (108 patients).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 72 intervention and 57 control patients, following a per-protocol approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The odds ratio for achieving the minimum clinically important difference in pain scores was 2.2 (95% CI 0.9 to 5.3; p = 0.08).
